user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 start_time, uint32 interval_time)
{
    OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t *local;
    struct itimerspec                   timeout;
    int32                               return_code;
    int                                 status;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *     timebase;

    local       = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_timebase_table, *token);
    timebase    = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, *token);
    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    /* There is only something to do here if we are generating a simulated tick */
    if (local->assigned_signal != 0)
    {
        /*
        ** Convert from Microseconds to timespec structures
        */
        memset(&timeout, 0, sizeof(timeout));
        OS_UsecToTimespec(start_time, &timeout.it_value);
        OS_UsecToTimespec(interval_time, &timeout.it_interval);

        /*
        ** Program the real timer
        */
        status = timer_settime(local->host_timerid, 0, /* Flags field can be zero */
                               &timeout,               /* struct itimerspec */
                               NULL);                  /* Oldvalue */

        if (status < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("Error in timer_settime: %s\n", strerror(errno));
            return_code = OS_TIMER_ERR_INTERNAL;
        }
        else if (interval_time > 0)
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_interval.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
        else
        {
            timebase->accuracy_usec = (uint32)((timeout.it_value.tv_nsec + 999) / 1000);
        }
    }

    local->reset_flag = (return_code == OS_SUCCESS);
    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseSet_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t OS_impl_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t       handler_thread;
    pthread_mutex_t handler_mutex;
    timer_t         host_timerid;
    int             assigned_signal;
    sigset_t        sigset;
    sig_atomic_t    reset_flag;
    struct timespec softsleep;
} OS_impl_timebase_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
static void OS_UsecToTimespec(uint32 usecs, struct timespec *time_spec)
{
    if (usecs < 1000000)
    {
        time_spec->tv_nsec = (usecs * 1000);
        time_spec->tv_sec  = 0;
    }
    else
    {
        time_spec->tv_sec  = usecs / 1000000;
        time_spec->tv_nsec = (usecs % 1000000) * 1000;
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in this implementation. The pointer parameter token is only read (used via OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET which ultimately calls OS_ObjectIndexFromToken with &(*token)), and there are no assignments to token itself. The scalar parameters start_time and interval_time are passed by value to OS_UsecToTimespec and otherwise only read or compared; they are not assigned to. Assignments in the function (for example local->reset_flag and timebase->accuracy_usec) modify objects obtained from the object tables, not the parameter variables themselves — modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule. All macro and function calls involved either take values or const pointers, so there is no hidden modification of the parameter variables. Therefore there are no code fragments that require further investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
